Understanding the Modern Military
Service Options

Types of Service

All Military careers are available as a full-time commitment; some of these careers have a part-time option. Helping your students understand the types of services available to the career paths theyâ€™ve expressed an interest in will contribute to their decision making.

Full Time

Full-time members of the Military serve on an Active Duty basis, with a time commitment similar to a full-time job. They are stationed at a base either domestically or overseas. In either of those situations, they may live on post, in military housing, or in civilian communities. Active-duty terms typically last two to six years, depending on the job and the amount of training necessary to qualify for that job. Just over one-half of all Service Members choose active service.

Part-Time

Part-time service members train one weekend a month and two weeks a year, allowing them time to pursue a civilian career or college. Part-time service options fall under three types: Reserve, National Guard, and Split Training.

Reserve

The purpose of the Reserve is to maintain trained service members to be made available for active duty as needed in times of war or national emergency. Each active-duty branch of the Military has a Reserve component under their command and some active-duty service members switch to the Reserve to finish out their service commitment. Reservists are likely to have civilian jobs outside their Reserve commitments.

Learn More

National Guard

The Guard focuses on homeland security and humanitarian relief. National Guard units assist communities in their state during emergencies like storms, floods, fires, and other natural disasters. The two Guard branches are the Army National Guard and the Air National Guard. Guard members can and are deployed outside the US in national and international engagements based on the needs of the nation.

Learn More

Split Training Option

The Army, Army National Guard, and Coast Guard offer a split training option in which students train for two summers and serve one weekend a month during the school year. Students are paid for their weekend service and begin Reserve duty once their training is complete. The Army and Army National Guard allow 17-year-olds, with parent/guardian consent, to begin training between their junior and senior years of high school. The Coast Guard requires the student to be attending a college or vocational school before participating in their split time program. Some branches allow college credit to be earned during split training.
